Award.AwardTitle: Deterministic and Stochastic Models of Water Limited Ecosystems: Implications of Pattern Formation, Bifurcations, Model Reduction, and Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator and her students will contribute to mathematical modeling efforts for desert ecosystems, which may be vulnerable to desertification under climate change. These models address the underlying mechanisms behind the spatial patterns of vegetation biomass that occur when certain semi-arid ecosystems are stressed by decreased precipitation. Interfacing self-organizing spatial effects for vegetation with the enormous variability of precipitation that define drylands suggests new directions for fundamental pattern formation research. The research will also contribute a mathematical framework for testing the robustness of the ecological proposals that the spatial patterns may serve as early warning signs of tipping points associated with climate change.

The research will be developed within a framework of deterministic and stochastic mathematical ecological models, with its objectives enhanced by the availability of rich satellite data that can be used to test model predictions. The first objective is to compare, qualitatively and quantitatively, a class of pattern-forming reaction-diffusion vegetation models to determine the robust transitions between distinct vegetation pattern states that may occur as the model system approaches its trivial desert state. This analysis will be based in bifurcation theory. The second objective is to develop and analyze vegetation models with temporally variable precipitation inputs, and spatially variable drainage networks. This will lead to the development of stochastic models with non-Gaussian noise. Model reduction methods will be used to further determine the consistency between model frameworks. Satellite image data of dry-land ecosystems will inform and verify the modeling effort. The project also has an education component with the goal of training undergraduate and graduate students in interdisciplinary applied mathematics research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project relates to mathematical modeling of arid and semi-arid ecosystems, and in particular, the formation of large-scale vegetation patterns and what they may tell us about the vulnerability of these ecosystems to climate change and other human impacts. The large-scale patterns are readily observed using satellite data of the type incorporated in google maps, and have been previously well documented in dryland regions in Africa, Australia and North America. The mechanisms behind their formation rely on key positive feedbacks between biomass and water infiltration during the rare rain storms. Typical hydrological timescales are hours, while biomass evolution, discernable between aerial images from the 1950s and modern satellite images, is decades.

Key project outcomes include (1) development of a fast-slow model framework that addresses the disparate timescales of the problem, (2) a modification of the fast-slow model to incorporate a stochastic precipitation model which requires more simulation time to obtain results, (3) examination of the impact, on shape of vegetation bands, of spatial heterogeneity in the form of topographic variation both within models and within satellite images, (4) development of tools to analyze satellite images together with the earliest aerial photographs of the vegetation patterns, and (5) training of a large group of junior researchers, at all levels from undergraduate to beginning faculty, in interdisciplinary applied mathematics research that is motivated by pressing environmental problems.

The project contributes to our understanding of pattern forming partial differential equations using tools of dynamical systems. Of particular interest to the field of pattern formation is the impact of some spatial variation of parameters of the problem, the impact of some stochasticity in driving inputs, and its fast-slow structure. The robustness of possible early warning signs, within patterns, of some imminent catastrophic collapse or tipping point was investigated from a number of angles: simulation, modeling, analysis, and the possible incorporation of satellite image data and elevation data.

Project results have been widely disseminated. They have been presented at a wide range of conferences, including plenary presentations at two major Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) applied mathematics meetings, and also at ecology workshops in the US, Israel, and the Netherlands. Project results have been published in peer reviewed journals. A chapter related to this project was written for the second edition of a dryland ecohydrology book. Presentations have been made to student groups, news articles for SIAM were published, and an interview on this project was conducted by the American Mathematical Society for their Mathematical Moments podcast, and posted on their YouTube channel.
